content:
ber 11, 2015
												So, finally completed this and although I liked the story, and it has the potential to contain a lot more depth than the newly released Chronicles (multiplayer support) I was a bit dissappointed that the story is quite linear, unless I am missing something here.I played through as a custom class Human, using Shotgun, Assault Rifle (both upto 6) with the maximum amount of charisma unlocked (to enable dialogue options) and some minor spirit control - for use on summon points.A lot of the extra etiquette options are null and void, each only being used once as far as I can see, and there are not many side missions, only encountered a single side mission, and one that was suggested as optional inbetween a major mission arc. (involving coyote)Combat is nice, tactical settings and options all very good - cover, scenery, summon points and ley lines adding to strategy level.The way you build your team can totally alter the playstyle you adopt, but overall you can ham fist your way through the majority of the missions with good combat skills. (with a solid main character at least)This was a real shame because although some levels were a challenge it was mainly because of a poor choice in a combat round (don't summon 3 spirits then have them go rogue woops) not because I struggled to overcome the enemies.This carried on right up until the end, again the only difficulty coming from the choice of enemy used to progress difficulty (spirits).Totally worth the time invested but I was expecting a lot more conversational choices (2 of the etiquette lines are not even used) and a LOT more side material in line with the none combat skills I only encountered 3 places in the game where I couldn't personally unlock, influence or action something because it was based on - decking, strength, or intelligence.Even race choice and stereotype seems to have little impact.I get that this is a showcase for the engine, and the ability to mod in more content is nice, but overall the vanilla campaign had a lot more potential than a basic manhunt combat run. imo

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2015
												TL;DR - Great story/setting, great character customisation, levels/gameplay is fairly linear which restricts the RPG elements of the game, overall a really fun game, worth the money, just have to take it as it is. Before I give my thoughts on this game, I'd like to make it clear that this is the first Shadowrun game I have played, although I am aware of the franchise and it's history. (Tabletop, PC/Console games etc.)Story/Setting: The game overall is pretty solid and good fun. It has a decent story with twists and turns and an amusing ending. You encounter likeable characters and the world is a great representation of Cyberpunk, with it's own take on things with the addition of magic.  Character Customisation:You get to make your own runner at the start of the game and there is a lot to work with from melee characters, armed characters, Deckers (hackers), Riggers (drones), Mages (spells, traps, heal), Shamans (Similar to mages, can also raise spirits, creatures and demons). However where this game shines is you really have the power to go all out with one type of class or mix any of them and make a unique build of your own. (I think I got all the classes correct there. Or near enough!) I'd say this game has great potential for replay value as you could try out all the different classes avaliable, however it wouldn't be something you'd jump straight back into after compleing in my opion, as the story and levels are fairly linear.Mechanics/Gameplay:Everything works as it should in this game and I encountered no issues at all. However I would say the game is a little lacking in RPG elements in my opinion. Let's call it CRPG-Lite! (That was terrible)A couple of areas that came to mind; In conversations you do have the ability to convice, bribe and use etiquettes to persuade and win people over to your side which you would expect with an RPG, but, what I feel was lacking was that you can't really ♥♥♥♥ someone off in dialogue or make them hate you and never talk to you again like you can in some RPGs, ultimately conversations (It would appear) all have the same conclusion, you just have little things you can do here and there if you spec'd in charisma, you bribe them or have the correct etiquette.I think this is because the levels and story are fairly linear for an RPG that it can't really give you that freedom. There are oppourtunities that you can miss out on if you give the wrong responses, but in an RPG I want it to be truly diverse in the sense that I can ♥♥♥♥ up an oppurtunity and then I have to go out of my way find another way to achieve my goal/quest. This game ultimately always seems to come to the same conclusion regardless. The other major area that felt a little lacking was the combat, it has the average top down, turn based combat mechanics but I wish it was more like Wasteland 2's. You can get behind cover, but some you can't shoot around, your character literally can't step out with one foot and shoot around a doorway or down a corridor. Just a bit more control over combat and the ability to make better stratergies would have made the combat near-perfect!Other little issues I had were things like not being able to examine the environments other than what the devs wanted you to see. Lack of dialogue/text box like in most RPGs, that displays examine text, Character thoughts and NPC dialogue etc.Overall:Overall this is a really fun game, I played it through in a few days and was pretty glued to it. At first I was a little disappointed with the lack of RPG elements I'm used to, but I quickly accepted that Shadowrun is it's own thing and does it a little differently. I'm really impressed with Harebrained Schemes and that they've successfully brought back Shadowrun. Now I have Dragonfall and Hong Kong to play, and from what I hear they've been improved a lot from this game!

content:
r 13, 2016
												After wanting to play Shadowrun for the longest time, tonight I finally finished it. The game was not that long with its 12 hours of game time, and to be honest, it was quite a disillusion. After finishing Baldur's Gate 1 for the first time two weeks ago, I was looking forward to another isometric RPG. Being a big Deus Ex fan, the cyberpunk theme of Shadowrun Returns was very alluring. Being unfamiliar with the Shadowrun franchise, the mix of cyberpunk and fantasy felt weird at first. But even in the end, I can't say that I like it better. I'll try to summarize my experience with this game in a pro/con list.PRO  The 2D backgrounds are from time to time quite beautiful  The user interface was quite ok, and looked sleek  The first half of the story was interesting  Interesting combination of combat going on in the matrix and in real life at the same time.  The game worked quite well on Linux (except for the remarks below)  The game was easy to play with keyboard and mouse, but also with the Steam Controller on my TVCON  The game did not handle "exotic" resolutions well. 3200x1800 on my linux laptop and 3440x1440 on my desktop were not manually selectable. Log files mentioned that the game detected the native resolution but a slightly different resolution was chosen. The drop down menu never showed the native resolutions in game. Full HD on my TV was easy.  When contacting the developer's support for the issue above, no support was given. I got an email confirming that they received my email, and that's the last thing that happened.  The loading screens took quite long for a "2D" game. I would expect it to be faster than games like Skyrim?  Classes seem very diverse, but they don't feel diverse.   Leveling is quite boring. Not a lot changes exect for some % to hit etcetera.  Fights are repetitive because there are not a lot of different tactics (necessary). The AI is not very bright.  During combat sequences the game goes turn-based, even when all enemies are killed you still keep walking turn based until you find new enemies in the same environment. Moving your whole team person by person is very tedious.  When going on missions you pay mercs to come with you. They are not very strong or optimal in their configuration, so they felt like dead weight compared to my maxed out SMG fighter.  Hacking/Matrix sequences are very repetitive. Both for the looks of the environment and the variation in enemies and variation in weapons. I just spammed my default attack and nothing else was needed.   The game is very linear. There are not a lot of side quests and you can't explore the world on your own. There is no open world to visit.  Because of the linear gameplay and uninteresting classes, replayability suffers a lot.  The story of the game started out great. It felt like a personal story compared to the "save the world" kind of stories from Skyrim and company. But from the middle of the game it felt like the writers had to keep making the story more elaborate to keep the gamers interested. They created some complex and unnecessary twists that ultimately made me just click faster through the conversation options because I became uninterested.  Those conversations were often very onesided. The choices you make in conversations almost never matter. Most answers are just different forms of the same answer, making conversations very uninteresting. There is no real impact on the game.  The writing of the game is obviously inspired by the Sprawl trilogy, and tiringly so. Every sentence tries to be drearier than the last one. I like film noir and cyberpunk, but this was way too cliché at times.  The world of Shadowrun combines cyberpunk and sci-fi with fantasy. Obviously a lot of people like this, but I'm not really fond of it. It gets worse when they try to mix even more classic (cliché?) game themes in the mix: violent crazy people in an asylum, undead ghouls, monsters and even spirits!! It just lacked some pirates and vampires...  The (hand drawn?) backgrounds were nice from time to time, but they are very empty. There is not a lot of animation or interactivity. The world feels dead.  The music is nice. I mean, the 3 or 4 tracks that are constantly repeated are nice the first time. They sound perfectly in line with the cyberpunk theme, but after having it on repeat for 12 hours, I just disabled the music altogether.   The game is quite short. I finished it in about 12 hours (thoroughly reading everything), and it seems like I'm slow compared to others. Some did it in 8 hours. Sadly, I was happy that it was over.I was looking forward to play the complete Shadowrun series, but after being let down by the first installment, I just can't bring myself to buy the sequels. Even if they are better... Too bad really! I hope that the other famous tactical 2D Kickstarter games like Wasteland 2 and Pillars of Eternity can make up for this game.

content:
16, 2014
												Shadowrun. I picked up the Pen and Paper RPG when I was younger. Sadly it took years before finding a group to play it. Luckly around my University years I found a decent group of people and we are gaming since than. I am an hardcore fan so probably my Review could be a bit biased. Frist of all I strongly suggest to read a bit before gaming. Just the "Primer" which is a small guide\introduction to the World of Shadowrun available from the site Shadowrun Universe (official site for all things related to Shadowrun). Once you have the Primer you can have a good idea of what to expect from the Setting. I know that at a frist glance it looks strange maybe even too much but trust me it is awesome. The more you will dig the better it will get, specially if you start to read the various RPG manuals and novels. If you liked the setting buy this game. The basic Campaign included in Shadowrun Returns is a classic. If you never rped or played Shadowrun (I am mostly referring to SNES and GENESIS Games) this is a wonderfull start. The narration is set in 2050s which is a very cool period for Shadowrun (keep in mind that in the current RP Setting the time is around 2075) and it is based on some of the hottest plots of that period. The game is a basic Turn Based Combat with RP elements in the form of dialogues where the various options depends on which skill you have. Back when it was just published the Game lacked few things like save anywhere option. Luckly this was fixed up in the 1st DLC Dragonfall. Dragonfall is even better than the basic game. The Devs listened to us Players and fixed few things and I dare to say even took inspiration from some of UGC - User generated Content (More of this later). Dragonfall can look a bit boring at the start with the logic of "Do a Run, get back and run again" (Run is a work, a mission in Shadowrun) but the Narration, the Plot goes always up till its end. In Dragonfall I was not impressed by the first Runs but nearby the end I could not stop to see how this Story was going to end. The only negative side of both Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall is that you can not manage your NPCs. You can select who can help you in a Run but you do not have any kind of control on their Skills and how they improve. Probably this will be fixed in future DLCs. If the basic game and the DLC are not enough there are UGCs. Shadowrun Community is very active and Devs select from time to time some UCG to play just to show up how much it is good. There are a lot of good Artist out there who are working on big UCG like remakes of SNES and Genesis Shadowrun Games. I strongly suggest to take a loot at "Shadowrun Unlimited". I hope all of this makes sense. In any case, if you start to play and dig into the Shadows of Shadowrun remember: "Shoot straight, conserve your ammo and never make a deal with a Dragon".

												Funded this game back when the kickstarter campaign was around. Spent $10, and would gladly spend $20+ on it. content:
er 3, 2013
												Back in my SNES days, Shadowrun was by far my favourite game.  These days, that's the only game that really sticks in my mind when I think back to playing that console.  Over the years I have tracked where the game was going.  Horrified that Microsoft bought the rights, but thought maybe they'll do something good with it.  Nope.  2007, I saw it was just another first-person shooter, not tied to the Shadowrun universe, I sadly concluded there was no chance of ever seeing another Shadowrun game like the one on SNES.  Guess I'll have to install a SNES emulator and play the original (never got around to it).Then I was cruising around Google Play last week, when Shadowrun Returns showed up on my recommended list.  OHHHH.... darn.  No tablet.  Yet.  But tis on Steam, and it works on Linux.  REJOICE!  I tried it for a few hours and so far it's looking great.  I played both the Dead Man's Switch campaign provided by Harebrained Schemes, and a story someone is putting together to replicate the SNES version.Thanks Microsoft for giving the game's rights back to Jordan Weisman!  Thanks Jordan and HBS for bringing back the world of Shadowrun to our screens!  Thanks  Kickstarter for the campaign to fund HBS' development.  Thanks all who provided funding!  Had I known the campaign existed last year, I would've contributed for sure.

												Shadowrun Returns is a tactical strategy rpg which functions similar to the X-Com or UFO series games, set in the Shadowrun universe. Pros: *Nice Artstyle*Simple yet effective combat and skill system, allows you to more or less build your "class" by picking which stats and skills you want to learn.*Lands the Shadowrun Universe pretty wellCons:*Very short playthrough (core game, not the Shadowrun: Dragonfall expansion)*This game is very easy on "normal". I recommend to anyone that has played the genre before to play on the hardest difficulties.*Could use more weapons/armor/configuration. I kept feeling like there should be another drop or weapon coming soon... and it never does.Overall: 7/10Fun game, looks nice, but it's very short and could use more content and story. I am about 5-6 hours in (2 did not get recorded by Steam), and I would say according to the chapter list on most websites I'm about 75% through the game. I am looking forward to trying the expansion however, and I will update my review when I get the chance. Many reviews for the expansion title seem to point out that it's a bit more complete and a touch longer than the core campaign.I would purchase this game again, since I bought it on sale... but I don't think I would pay full price for it. This is a good pickup if you catch it on sale, and if so I would grab the expansion to go with it, otherwise the game may feel a bit incomplete.

												Overall, I would give this game a 9/10. Everything is fantastic, and I cannot wait to play Dragonfall someday and also play player-created campaigns. I am also inspired to pick up the paper and pen version of Shadowrun, as well as Shadowrun Online. It's just that Dead Man's Switch became quite disappointing. Just take it out, or give the players more freedom, and everything here would be stellar.*****Now for ***SPOILERS*** Kind of.*****I have not played Dragonfall, so this review is of the main campaign, Dead Man's Switch. I really enjoy pretty much every aspect of this game--the environment, combat, characters, atmosphere, etc.--except for the main story. Despite getting very interested in the storyline after the first few lines were presented to me, almost all of my excitement was lost when the Ripper was revealed. I was having fun treating DMS as a murder mystery; I was carefully examining everything and trying to figure out who the Ripper could be--I even had some evidence to support who I thought could be the Ripper--but the game pretty much points a huge sign at the real suspect from the moment they are introduced, and this is overwhelmingly disappointing. The other side of the story after the reveal doesn't even make much sense.

er 23, 2015
												Shadowrun returns was a kickstarter project that gained traction rather fast, although like most kickstarters this was due to nostalgia. This game stands on its own extremely well.Shadowrun returns is a cyberpunk fantasy tactical rpg, which in retrospective sounds absurd but its an idea that works really well and is amplified by the impressive dungeons and dragons art style.Typical for an RPG you level up with points gained from battles but what you put your points into in this case either help you or hinder you.Upgrades are apart of the experience and have a tradeoff mechanic, sacrificing one thing to gain something else, but comes into play later in the game.During my time with the game the battles were more interesting than the story and in an rpg story should be just as important as the rest of the game.The game stands on its own legs and is a good experience for someone who enjoys strategic rpg games and/or cyberpunk settingsRating: 8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
29, 2015
												A tale of two halves.The first half is a basic-yet-intriguing cyberpunk XCOM-lite game. The second is a tedious, monotonous, dragged-out affair that completely spoils everything and made me very glad it was only $2.50 when I picked it up.PROS-Crisp art style that lends itself fairly well to the setting-Some interesting characters (kind of)-The music is decent the first time around-Neat outfits-It's less than ten hours....CONS-Environments/levels are 99% static and lifeless-The dialogue/script is wildly inconsistent in terms of style, going from grandiose to vernacular at will. It's like two or three different guys were writing without consulting the design document. Then at the end they were just like "♥♥♥♥ it, too hard to redo all this work"-After a couple hours, the music grates-Combat is far too simple to be enjoyable for long-Lack of cool loot/drops-Exceedingly linear-Most characters are neat at first but then it becomes obvious there's no depth-The narrative takes a wild shift in the second half, and it's not for the betterment of the game-The second half is only more difficult because gobs of enemies are thrown at you, rather than anything clever or original-Puzzles can all be solved by holding down Alt to see what few things are interactive-Terrible ending that made me uninstall immediately after closing the game-Along with the tonal shifts, most of the scant humor isn't funny, and the cyberpunk/Shadowrun terms were used in a tryharding manner rather than making sense or adding atmosphere-Lots of typos and generally-lazy writing-Decking is uselessly dullOverall it's a game that starts out strong and finishes way after boredom sets in. The combat is stale with little-to-no tactical depth, and level design is so narrow-sighted and basic that I can't help but think these guys are out of their league. And this is from someone who views cyberpunk as the best genre in all of media.

content:
1, 2014
												The Dragonfall expansion single-handedly did justice to Shadowrun Returns. The Dragonfall campaign build brings a much more involving and intricate storyline, choices, side-missions and memorable NPC companions, resulting in longer gameplay and satisfaction compared to the 12-hour long original. There were certain tweaks to the mechanics of the core game, it seems. For example, there will no longer be extra action points garnered from cybernetics, but this is compensated for via game balancing. There are new portraits to choose from (though still quite limited visual customization) but no changes to the skill trees. Games can be saved at almost every point of the game now, not just at savepoints, so that's another step forward. There are new music scores with this campaign, and they all set the mood satisfactorily for the throughout the gameplay. I still find the beats from the original campaign more to my liking, but that's personal opinion. Some issues inherent in the original was still present in this one. Missing sprites, limitations to allocating picked-up items to teammates outside of combat and the occassional AP bug can still be encountered. However, I would not personally hold this against the expansion as this one is does seem like the developer's turn of churning out an AAA campaign using the same builder tools made available to the community. I grew up playing and loving role-playing games that were akin to reading sci-fi fantasy book sets. After Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, Arcanum and Neverwinter Nights, I am relieved to be able to add Shadowrun Returns into my collection of RPG games worth the ages. To enjoy this one, you'll have to read, children, and dig into your storeroom for that old thing called an 'active imagination'. If Shadowrun Returns left you feeling wanting, then Dragonfall will bring you past dessert.

content:
25, 2014
												If you're a Shadowrun fan, or at least have some experience with the old SNES and/or Genesis games (the 2006 Xbox one doesn't count), this is worth picking up. Shadowrun Returns plays like XCOM with more RPG elements and without the punishing difficulty that is a hallmark of that series. The story is full of references and inside jokes that will render fans of the series nostalgic, but even if you're new to the series, important concepts and characters are explained at least adequately enough for the story to make sense. My one complaint is that the story, which is fairly short, is extremely linear and offers virtually no sidequesting. However, this game is meant to be just one "campaign" in the Shadowrun setting, and the real replay value lies in the editor, which allows players to create their own adventures and share them with the world. Despite its linearity and lack of meaningful choices for the player to make, I say buying it is justified by its low price tag. I hope this game helps give the Shadowrun setting more publicity, because it's definitely unique and worth investigating.

content:

												Great game! I've never reviewed one before, but I think this a real hidden gem. The graphics are lush and immersive, player creation is simple but very detailed. The abilities, classes, and combat are very true to the paper and pencil Shadowrun RPG (which is great). NPC dialog and dialog response options are some of the best I've ever seen in a game. They really went all out with this one, even more impressive because it was made by a realtively small developer (I'm going to look for more games from Harbrained after playing this).Best feature of all though, great TURN-BASED rpg combat. Reminiscent of some of the best rpgs ever made, but with gorgeous graphics thrown in. I would recommend the Dragonfall scenario too, just because this game is so good, one story isn't enough!Also, I got the core game on sale for just $5, literally best five dollars I've ever spent!The dev team really hit it out of the park on this one, I'll be looking for more of your games and any future kickstarters you do, please keep up the amazing work!

												*i've only beaten Dead Man's Switch and my short rant will only conver it*My first impression of this game was really great and i was really impressed by the story wirting , art direction and character building but as i progressed through the game its flaws have became more apparent .Story wirting is good through out the whole game and the writer/s seems like a knowledgeable person but i was really surprised when i noticed spelling and grammer mistakes! For me it wasn't a big problem since English is not my native language but i think many native-English gamers will find it annoying .The gameplay machanics are good but have small problems that can be annoying at times .Some of them are technical (like when you set the character to overwatch a certain enemy/area and then it goes out of the previously set range and waste a bullet and an AP point) and some of them are design flaws (like being forced to traverse a whole floor in battle mode even if there is no enemy left) .For the game design in general i really wished that the developers have reused the previously visted locations for side-missions to increase the game time and value because in the end this is an RPG game and not COD .This game have its flaws but i was able to look past them and enjoy it .That's why i'm recommending it .

												Shadowrun Returns is a decent CRPG that has definite bona fides back to the isometric giants of ages past.  The content is well written and fits the universe it's set in.  The combat is fun, if a bit less than challenging and less common then you'd hope.The game does feel a bit "on rails", however, especially when compared to the games it harkens back to.  This isn't the utter gigantism of something like Baldur's Gate.  The game is pretty small, the party options are limited (you only get to allocate stats and alter the inventory of the main character, for example).  I bought SRR during the steam summer sale.  It was worth the $3.50, easily.  I'm hoping to discover a lot of additional content in the workshop.

content:
2, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a surprisingly addictive isometric cyberpunk RPG. The combat has enough tactical depth to keep you on your toes, but the real strength to this game is the story. The dialogue between characters is both interesting and meaningful, often making use of slang specific to the Shadowrun universe which aids immersion. The game does feel quite linear at times and conversational options are often inconsequential, but it doesn't detract from the experience thanks to engaging storyline. I'm genuinely surprised at the quality of the game, especially when consideration is given to the asking price. I think anyone looking for a modern take on old-school RPG'ing would be wise to try Shadowrun.Note: ignore the playtime, my shadowrunning was done offline.

												I've never played the Shadowrun tabletop RPG, those aren't my bag. I did love the Shadowrun game on SNES that I played as a kid. This game brings a good blend of nostaglia for that previous title in a similar, but updated look, but it definitely also takes advantage of lessons learned in gaming in the intervening years. Combat in both the real world and while dekking is intuitive and easy to grasp. There are a number of skill tree options to monkey with, but not so many as to require a spreadsheet. Overall I found the game to be a satisfying experience, not terribly difficult, but that's not what I was looking for here anyway. Good times, definitely worth picking up if you enjoyed the old SNES game or the trailer to this one appeals to you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												The Dead Man's Switch(DMS) campaign is forgettable and is only notable for having an annoying enemy that can only be killed with a cumbersome mechanic. There are a handful of interesting interactions during DMS but overall its honestly not worth playing through and can be easily skipped.Dragonfall(DF), on the other hand, is awesome and is filled with characters and scenarios that are as imaginative, well written,  and worth exploring as some of the best RPGs that I have ever played. DF additionally contains a much better structure than DMS, by that I mean rather than having a linear quest with hardly any side branches that you undertake with some flavorless NPCs, DF tasks you with a central goal and allows you to lead a team of fairly unique characters along a questline that has scores of opportunity to explore more of the world of Shadowrun. I enjoyed the vast majority of my time with DF, save for the hacking bits (called decking in this universe), and some later game fights with some annoyingly powerful enemies. Altough, I wholeheartedly recommend DF, Its a shame that you have to buy both to play DF but since thats the case I would advise that you buy the campaigns at a reduced cost and skip DMS.

												This game is quite the nostalgia trip. They really nailed the look and feel of gritty ol' Seattle of 2054, and the music is just stellar. It's an old view of the future, played in the old ways of RPGs. That means lots of turn-based combat and lots of reading. LOTS of reading. The story is nothing stellar -- what Shadowrun fiction ever is -- but it's a fun return to familiar territory. I haven't dug into the user-generated stuff, but the main campaign is easily worth the asking price if you have any love of cyberpunk.That said, if you buy this, then I highly recommend picking up the Dragonfall expansion as well. It's storyline is much, much better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
												Gameplay is topnotch Tactical RPG stuff. Its fun to make your character however you'd like them, and the skills are laid out in a straightforward way. Spell variety leaves a little bit left to be desired, and I personally wouldve liked greater variety for implants, but is all in all very solid. Storyline for the default game, called "The Deadman's Switch" is boring and linear, and you dont spend a long enough amount of downtime to talk to and connect with your party members. Also playing a decker is a waste of time as theres very few times you actually get to enter the Matrix. Hold your hand too much and feels shallow because of itThe DLC, Dragonfall, fixes the above problems. It starts a bit linear just like before, but theres multiple ways to clear any area, as well as plenty of time between missions to talk with your fellow Shadowrunners. The plot is much more interesting and there are more ways to use your character's skills, both in the field, and in dialogue choices. The game opens up and you get to start taking missions of your own accord, with each having a small storyline within its own mission.Theres also a metric crapton of great workshop content out for the game, which I think will add tremendously to the games longevity.Bottomline, buy this game, and buy it with the DLC.

												The core campaign here, Dead Man's Switch, is awful.  It serves as an introduction to the mechanics and, to a much lesser extent, the setting of Shadowrun.  The DLC/expansion Dragonfall, however, is absolutely fantastic, and is completely unrelated to the core campaign.  It's one of the better written RPGs I've ever played.  The characters are great, the story is interesting, the decisions are difficult, and although the "epilogue" is a little weak, the overall ending was solid.  I heartily recommend Dragonfall to any RPG enthusiast and especially to anyone who has ever been curious to explore the Shadowrun setting.

content:
3, 2014
												Graphics - 4/5A fantastic pre-rendered world that looks fantastic almost everywhere. There are some flickering issues in some areas and some of the larger creatures aren't high resolution friendly.Sound - 3/5Nothing incredibly memorable, BUT, it is absolutely perfect for the setting and really sets the mood of this bleak futuristic world.Gameplay - 5/5Best tactical RPG I've ever played. You can make whatever kind of character you want. My character used nothing but his fists and knuckle weapons and he ended up being a badass knocking security bots out with a single punch. The combat itself is awesome, fast paced and controls really well. One thing that I noticed though was I feel like the percentages are a little off for the accuracy ratings, I feel like I've rarely hit anything lower than 60 percent.Story - 4.5/5This is a review of the Dragonfall story. You follow a group of shadowrunners led by your character, and the game really makes you familiar with everyone. All species of sentient beings have their own ways of speaking and there are very little stereotypical characters. Strong female leads, strong male leads, and all around strong side characters. Dead Man's Switch overplayed the in world slang a little bit too much, but Dragonfall made it very easy to get what certain words mean.Overall: 4/5

												The game story and mechanics seems rushed however, the graphics were quite nice and a little too "fluffy" for this style of game.  The music, not a fan, it still lingers in my head after the game crashes or I die and have to go back to that base to redo many lost hours of gameplay. Cheap deaths are understandable as they make you re-strategize...but it wouldn't of been so bad EXCEPT not being able to save whenever you want was very annyoing.  The game did have tense moments mostly because I was afraid to die because I didn't to have to replay the entire mission.  The game seemed to have a tutorial guided aspect...go here and click this.One thing I did like, irrigardless what I stated above, was the story.  I found it interesting and kept playing to see what was going to come next.  The added dark humor was relavent to its style and I enjoyed it.

content:
, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a game I find hard to give excessive praise, but it's a game that I also find hard to dislike. When it comes down to it, it's a completely solid game, even if it's shallow. Nevertheless, I enjoyed it and feel fully satisfied with the experience, and I didn't have any trouble playing all the way through. There are certainly some notable flaws, however.Let's start with the story, since this game relies heavily on it's writing to motivate the player. The writing and characterization is good, I felt very absorbed in the universe, but the story itself is fairly lacking. It's a shame as well, it starts out great. You got a murder mystery with a lot of interesting faces dying to be talked to, with a few twists and turns here and there. The problem is that it just doesn't developed. It feels extremely rushed. The characters are lovable and relatable to the very end, but I started skipping through dialogue that dealt with the actual plot about 2/3rds through the game. It escalates in a comical direction, with an extremely weak and one-dimensional villian. It's extremely predictable, and just plain boring. The last stretch is so typical and lackluster that I had little to no investment in the actual plight, I just wanted to see if the characters would drop some more interesting backstory about themselves. It gave me closure, but it's not memorable at all. It's just too bad, the beginning was really good, but the plot started going so fast in such a linear direction that it forgot to flesh itself out, leaving some questions unanswered and plot points underdeveloped. It got the job done, but I was hoping for more.Where the game really shines are the characters and their own personal issues. Almost all the staple characters have their own personal motives and vendettas, and I was interested in all their stories. I enjoyed going back to base and talking to every single one of them that were willing to open their mouths. The game does a fantastic job of setting up this belonging feeling, that you're part of this organization of runners. Although, as I stated before, as the game escalates it leaves behind this deep characterization in order to fawn over its own hilariously absurd and out-of-place world-threatening dilemma.The combat is serviceable. It's ultimately shallow and linear, there isn't a lot of variation or depth, and there are some balance issues. But it's still fun, you get to characterize some characters simply by their fighting styles. It's too easy as well, but not game-ruiningly so. It's fun, if you really like X-COM-like turn based combat, you'll probably enjoy it if you can stand it being a tad shallow.The game is overall fun, I would recommend it. It doesn't really have any offending flaws, it just doesn't quite reach the large potential it could've. It's not particularly memorable, but it's enjoyable. I would wait for a sale, but when the price is suitable to you, I'd say to go for it just to get immersed in the world.

content:
, 2014
												Once I sorted out the crashing issues, (Thanks to this website http://shadowrun-returns.wikispaces.com/Troubleshooting+FAQ, I did the "Audio Problems" fix, and run the game in 1024x768) the game works fine. I will admit I never played any of the older versions, but Shadowrun Online has been on my wish list for a while and when I seen Shadowrun Returns for under $5 (I love you Steam Summer Sale), I snapped it up quick. After playing for only 15 mins, I was sad I never played the older versions, and I was doubly sad I never even heard about the Shadowrun series until this year.As for this iteration of the Shadowrun series, I was blown away, when one of the NPC's feels an urgency to get a mission done, that sense of urgency if felt by the player too. I'm looking your way Paco.The sound effects are really well put together, there is something satisfying about beaning a thug over the head with a baseball bat and that bone on wood sound chimes in......... (Makes note to get more baseball bats in game.)The dreary, miserable, wet, outside world is not only a joy (in the sense it feels real) to walk around in, it is also a joy to explore and talk to the locals and see how downtrodden they are as well.The loading screen DM style scene setting briefs even make the game feel like you could almost be playing the tabletop version with a friend over the weekend.Game play 10/10Graphics 10/10Music 10/10SFX 10/10Atmosphere 15/10All in All 10/10 will spend WAY to many hours playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
9, 2014
												This review is for Shadowrun Unlimited....a dlc created by Southwind. Basically, this add on takes Shadowrun Returns & makes it the game it should have been. Don't get me wrong, SR is a very good game in itself but it tells a very linear story that takes around 12 hrs to complete. What Southwind did was take the basic gameplay & created a sandbox like game that a lot of fans of the table top version were hoping for. In Unlimited you have a back story of avenging your brother but while trying to accomplish this you have to become an experienced runner first. To accomplish this you start gaining contacts for different job types you can choose from such as being a bodyguard, cleaning up problems, asassination & delivery jobs. You also meet other runners which you can contact to help you on the different jobs you take on. You have  a lot more different areas you can travel to & different options to complete your missions. I've played about 4 hrs at the time of this review & I am still working on just building my character up for better jobs. That is what makes Unlimited so much better than SR....it gives you a feeling of being in the Shadowrun world rather then just getting to the end of a story.Unlimited introduces some very cool game elements that expands on the game & helps make you feel even more in this world. You can rent different safehouses to heal between missions & store your gear. You also have 3 new "stats" to check on. Street cred, which affects the quality of missions you can get. There is noteriety, which can cause you problems with the different gangs & corps. Lastly, there is heat. This one is for how the Lone Stars (cops) treat you.My understanding (this is the best part) is that there is no "end game" for this. Southwind & others are working to continually expand on what is already in play by adding more missions, maps & characters. My only hope is that once the backstory is finished a new one will take it's place. The only downside to this game is I don't think you can import an already created character but it is definately worth starting a new one for this.In closing I feel that Unlimited took what the dev's put together & made it so much better. If you already have SR than this is a must have. If not but were thinking about it Unlimited should give you that little push to get the original just so you can jump into this excellently done add on. Oh, by the way, Unlimited (not Shadowrun Returns) is free.

content:
1, 2014
												The Dragonfall expansion single-handedly did justice to Shadowrun Returns. The Dragonfall campaign build brings a much more involving and intricate storyline, choices, side-missions and memorable NPC companions, resulting in longer gameplay and satisfaction compared to the 12-hour long original. There were certain tweaks to the mechanics of the core game, it seems. For example, there will no longer be extra action points garnered from cybernetics, but this is compensated for via game balancing. There are new portraits to choose from (though still quite limited visual customization) but no changes to the skill trees. Games can be saved at almost every point of the game now, not just at savepoints, so that's another step forward. There are new music scores with this campaign, and they all set the mood satisfactorily for the throughout the gameplay. I still find the beats from the original campaign more to my liking, but that's personal opinion. Some issues inherent in the original was still present in this one. Missing sprites, limitations to allocating picked-up items to teammates outside of combat and the occassional AP bug can still be encountered. However, I would not personally hold this against the expansion as this one is does seem like the developer's turn of churning out an AAA campaign using the same builder tools made available to the community. I grew up playing and loving role-playing games that were akin to reading sci-fi fantasy book sets. After Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, Arcanum and Neverwinter Nights, I am relieved to be able to add Shadowrun Returns into my collection of RPG games worth the ages. To enjoy this one, you'll have to read, children, and dig into your storeroom for that old thing called an 'active imagination'. If Shadowrun Returns left you feeling wanting, then Dragonfall will bring you past dessert.
